speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The Parliament-house.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Alarum. Enter YORK, EDWARD, RICHARD, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, WARWICK, and Soldiers

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I wonder how the king escaped our hands.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: While we pursued the horsemen of the north,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He slily stole away and left his men:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Whose warlike ears could never brook retreat,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Cheer'd up the drooping army; and himself,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford, all abreast,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Charged our main battle's front, and breaking in

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Were by the swords of common soldiers slain.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Lord Stafford's father, Duke of Buckingham,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Is either slain or wounded dangerously;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I cleft his beaver with a downright blow:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That this is true, father, behold his blood.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And, brother, here's the Earl of Wiltshire's blood,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Whom I encounter'd as the battles join'd.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Speak thou for me and tell them what I did.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Throwing down SOMERSET's head

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Richard hath best deserved of all my sons.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But is your grace dead, my Lord of Somerset?

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: Such hope have all the line of John of Gaunt!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And so do I. Victorious Prince of York,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Before I see thee seated in that throne

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Which now the house of Lancaster usurps,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I vow by heaven these eyes shall never close.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: This is the palace of the fearful king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And this the regal seat: possess it, York;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For this is thine and not King Henry's heirs'

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Assist me, then, sweet Warwick, and I will;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: For hither we have broken in by force.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: We'll all assist you; he that flies shall die.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thanks, gentle Norfolk: stay by me, my lords;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And, soldiers, stay and lodge by me this night.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: They go up

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And when the king comes, offer no violence,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unless he seek to thrust you out perforce.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The queen this day here holds her parliament,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: But little thinks we shall be of her council:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: By words or blows here let us win our right.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Arm'd as we are, let's stay within this house.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The bloody parliament shall this be call'd,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Unless Plantagenet, Duke of York, be king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And bashful Henry deposed, whose cowardice

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Hath made us by-words to our enemies.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then leave me not, my lords; be resolute;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I mean to take possession of my right.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Neither the king, nor he that loves him best,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The proudest he that holds up Lancaster,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Dares stir a wing, if Warwick shake his bells.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I'll plant Plantagenet, root him up who dares:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Resolve thee, Richard; claim the English crown.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, CLIFFORD, NORTHUMBERLAND, WESTMORELAND, EXETER, and the rest

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My lords, look where the sturdy rebel sits,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Even in the chair of state: belike he means,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Back'd by the power of Warwick, that false peer,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To aspire unto the crown and reign as king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And thine, Lord Clifford; and you both have vow'd revenge

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: On him, his sons, his favourites and his friends.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: If I be not, heavens be revenged on me!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The hope thereof makes Clifford mourn in steel.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: What, shall we suffer this? let's pluck him down:

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: My heart for anger burns; I cannot brook it.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be patient, gentle Earl of Westmoreland.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Patience is for poltroons, such as he:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He durst not sit there, had your father lived.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My gracious lord, here in the parliament

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Let us assail the family of York.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Well hast thou spoken, cousin: be it so.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, know you not the city favours them,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And they have troops of soldiers at their beck?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But when the duke is slain, they'll quickly fly.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To make a shambles of the parliament-house!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Cousin of Exeter, frowns, words and threats

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shall be the war that Henry means to use.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: and kneel for grace and mercy at my feet;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am thy sovereign.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I am thine.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: For shame, come down: he made thee Duke of York.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Twas my inheritance, as the earldom was.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Thy father was a traitor to the crown.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In following this usurping Henry.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Whom should he follow but his natural king?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: True, Clifford; and that's Richard Duke of York.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And shall I stand, and thou sit in my throne?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: It must and shall be so: content thyself.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Be Duke of Lancaster; let him be king.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: He is both king and Duke of Lancaster;

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: And that the Lord of Westmoreland shall maintain.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And Warwick shall disprove it. You forget

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That we are those which chased you from the field

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And slew your fathers, and with colours spread

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: March'd through the city to the palace gates.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Yes, Warwick, I remember it to my grief;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And, by his soul, thou and thy house shall rue it.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Plantagenet, of thee and these thy sons,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Thy kinsman and thy friends, I'll have more lives

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Than drops of blood were in my father's veins.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Urge it no more; lest that, instead of words,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I send thee, Warwick, such a messenger

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: As shall revenge his death before I stir.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Poor Clifford! how I scorn his worthless threats!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Will you we show our title to the crown?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If not, our swords shall plead it in the field.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What title hast thou, traitor, to the crown?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am the son of Henry the Fifth,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Who made the Dauphin and the French to stoop

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And seized upon their towns and provinces.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Talk not of France, sith thou hast lost it all.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The lord protector lost it, and not I:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When I was crown'd I was but nine months old.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: You are old enough now, and yet, methinks, you lose.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Father, tear the crown from the usurper's head.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Sweet father, do so; set it on your head.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Good brother, as thou lovest and honourest arms,

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Let's fight it out and not stand cavilling thus.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Sound drums and trumpets, and the king will fly.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Sons, peace!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Peace, thou! and give King Henry leave to speak.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Plantagenet shall speak first: hear him, lords;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And be you silent and attentive too,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For he that interrupts him shall not live.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Think'st thou that I will leave my kingly throne,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Wherein my grandsire and my father sat?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No: first shall war unpeople this my realm;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, and their colours, often borne in France,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And now in England to our heart's great sorrow,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Shall be my winding-sheet. Why faint you, lords?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My title's good, and better far than his.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Prove it, Henry, and thou shalt be king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Henry the Fourth by conquest got the crown.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Twas by rebellion against his king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: [Aside]  I know not what to say; my title's weak.--

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tell me, may not a king adopt an heir?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What then?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: An if he may, then am I lawful king;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For Richard, in the view of many lords,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Resign'd the crown to Henry the Fourth,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose heir my father was, and I am his.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He rose against him, being his sovereign,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And made him to resign his crown perforce.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Suppose, my lords, he did it unconstrain'd,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Think you 'twere prejudicial to his crown?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: No; for he could not so resign his crown

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: But that the next heir should succeed and reign.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Art thou against us, Duke of Exeter?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Why whisper you, my lords, and answer not?

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: My conscience tells me he is lawful king.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: [Aside]  All will revolt from me, and turn to him.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Plantagenet, for all the claim thou lay'st,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Think not that Henry shall be so deposed.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Thou art deceived: 'tis not thy southern power,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Of Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, nor of Kent,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Which makes thee thus presumptuous and proud,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Can set the duke up in despite of me.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: King Henry, be thy title right or wrong,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Lord Clifford vows to fight in thy defence:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: May that ground gape and swallow me alive,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O Clifford, how thy words revive my heart!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Henry of Lancaster, resign thy crown.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What mutter you, or what conspire you, lords?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Do right unto this princely Duke of York,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or I will fill the house with armed men,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And over the chair of state, where now he sits,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Write up his title with usurping blood.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: He stamps with his foot and the soldiers show themselves

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My Lord of Warwick, hear me but one word:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let me for this my life-time reign as king.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And thou shalt reign in quiet while thou livest.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am content: Richard Plantagenet,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: What wrong is this unto the prince your son!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What good is this to England and himself!

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Base, fearful and despairing Henry!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: How hast thou injured both thyself and us!

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: I cannot stay to hear these articles.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Nor I.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Come, cousin, let us tell the queen these news.

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: Farewell, faint-hearted and degenerate king,

speaker: WESTMORELAND
text_entry: In whose cold blood no spark of honour bides.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Be thou a prey unto the house of York,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And die in bands for this unmanly deed!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: In dreadful war mayst thou be overcome,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Or live in peace abandon'd and despised!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Exeunt NORTHUMBERLAND, CLIFFORD, and WESTMORELAND

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Turn this way, Henry, and regard them not.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: They seek revenge and therefore will not yield.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, Exeter!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why should you sigh, my lord?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Not for myself, Lord Warwick, but my son,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whom I unnaturally shall disinherit.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But be it as it may: I here entail

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The crown to thee and to thine heirs for ever;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Conditionally, that here thou take an oath

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To cease this civil war, and, whilst I live,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To honour me as thy king and sovereign,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And neither by treason nor hostility

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To seek to put me down and reign thyself.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: This oath I willingly take and will perform.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Long live King Henry! Plantagenet embrace him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And long live thou and these thy forward sons!

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Now York and Lancaster are reconciled.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Accursed be he that seeks to make them foes!

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Sennet. Here they come down

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Farewell, my gracious lord; I'll to my castle.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And I'll keep London with my soldiers.

speaker: NORFOLK
text_entry: And I to Norfolk with my followers.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: And I unto the sea from whence I came.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Exeunt YORK, EDWARD, EDMUND, GEORGE, RICHARD,  WARWICK, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, their Soldiers, and Attendants

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And I, with grief and sorrow, to the court.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Here comes the queen, whose looks bewray her anger:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: I'll steal away.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeter, so will I.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Nay, go not from me; I will follow thee.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be patient, gentle queen, and I will stay.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Who can be patient in such extremes?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ah, wretched man! would I had died a maid

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And never seen thee, never borne thee son,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Seeing thou hast proved so unnatural a father

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hath he deserved to lose his birthright thus?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hadst thou but loved him half so well as I,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Or felt that pain which I did for him once,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Or nourish'd him as I did with my blood,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blood there,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Rather than have that savage duke thine heir

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And disinherited thine only son.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Father, you cannot disinherit me:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: If you be king, why should not I succeed?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Pardon me, Margaret; pardon me, sweet son:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The Earl of Warwick and the duke enforced me.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Enforced thee! art thou king, and wilt be forced?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I shame to hear thee speak. Ah, timorous wretch!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou hast undone thyself, thy son and me;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And given unto the house of York such head

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As thou shalt reign but by their sufferance.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To entail him and his heirs unto the crown,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What is it, but to make thy sepulchre

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And creep into it far before thy time?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Stern Falconbridge commands the narrow seas;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The duke is made protector of the realm;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And yet shalt thou be safe? such safety finds

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The trembling lamb environed with wolves.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Had I been there, which am a silly woman,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The soldiers should have toss'd me on their pikes

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Before I would have granted to that act.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But thou preferr'st thy life before thine honour:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And seeing thou dost, I here divorce myself

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Both from thy table, Henry, and thy bed,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Until that act of parliament be repeal'd

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Whereby my son is disinherited.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The northern lords that have forsworn thy colours

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Will follow mine, if once they see them spread;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And spread they shall be, to thy foul disgrace

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And utter ruin of the house of York.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thus do I leave thee. Come, son, let's away;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Our army is ready; come, we'll after them.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Stay, gentle Margaret, and hear me speak.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, to be murder'd by his enemies.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: When I return with victory from the field

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I'll see your grace: till then I'll follow her.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Come, son, away; we may not linger thus.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exeunt QUEEN MARGARET and PRINCE EDWARD

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Poor queen! how love to me and to her son

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Hath made her break out into terms of rage!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Revenged may she be on that hateful duke,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose haughty spirit, winged with desire,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Will cost my crown, and like an empty eagle

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The loss of those three lords torments my heart:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I'll write unto them and entreat them fair.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Come, cousin you shall be the messenger.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: And I, I hope, shall reconcile them all.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: SCENE II. Sandal Castle.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Enter RICHARD, EDWARD, and MONTAGUE

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Brother, though I be youngest, give me leave.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: No, I can better play the orator.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: But I have reasons strong and forcible.

speaker: MONTAGUE
text_entry: Enter YORK

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Why, how now, sons and brother! at a strife?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What is your quarrel? how began it first?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: No quarrel, but a slight contention.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: About what?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: About that which concerns your grace and us;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The crown of England, father, which is yours.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Mine boy? not till King Henry be dead.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Your right depends not on his life or death.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now you are heir, therefore enjoy it now:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: By giving the house of Lancaster leave to breathe,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: It will outrun you, father, in the end.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I took an oath that he should quietly reign.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: But for a kingdom any oath may be broken:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I would break a thousand oaths to reign one year.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: No; God forbid your grace should be forsworn.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I shall be, if I claim by open war.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I'll prove the contrary, if you'll hear me speak.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: An oath is of no moment, being not took

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Before a true and lawful magistrate,

speaker: RICHARD

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Methinks, 'tis prize enough to be his son.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: See how the morning opes her golden gates,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And takes her farewell of the glorious sun!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: How well resembles it the prime of youth,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Trimm'd like a younker prancing to his love!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Not separated with the racking clouds,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But sever'd in a pale clear-shining sky.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: See, see! they join, embrace, and seem to kiss,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As if they vow'd some league inviolable:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Now are they but one lamp, one light, one sun.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: In this the heaven figures some event.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: 'Tis wondrous strange, the like yet never heard of.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I think it cites us, brother, to the field,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That we, the sons of brave Plantagenet,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Each one already blazing by our meeds,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Should notwithstanding join our lights together

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And over-shine the earth as this the world.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Whate'er it bodes, henceforward will I bear

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Upon my target three fair-shining suns.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nay, bear three daughters: by your leave I speak it,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: You love the breeder better than the male.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But what art thou, whose heavy looks foretell

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Some dreadful story hanging on thy tongue?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ah, one that was a woful looker-on

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: When as the noble Duke of York was slain,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your princely father and my loving lord!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O, speak no more, for I have heard too much.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Say how he died, for I will hear it all.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Environed he was with many foes,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And stood against them, as the hope of Troy

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Against the Greeks that would have enter'd Troy.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But Hercules himself must yield to odds;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And many strokes, though with a little axe,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Hew down and fell the hardest-timber'd oak.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: By many hands your father was subdued;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: But only slaughter'd by the ireful arm

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of unrelenting Clifford and the queen,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Who crown'd the gracious duke in high despite,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Laugh'd in his face; and when with grief he wept,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The ruthless queen gave him to dry his cheeks

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A napkin steeped in the harmless blood

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Of sweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford slain:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And after many scorns, many foul taunts,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They took his head, and on the gates of York

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: They set the same; and there it doth remain,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The saddest spectacle that e'er I view'd.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Sweet Duke of York, our prop to lean upon,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now thou art gone, we have no staff, no stay.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O Clifford, boisterous Clifford! thou hast slain

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: The flower of Europe for his chivalry;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And treacherously hast thou vanquish'd him,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For hand to hand he would have vanquish'd thee.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now my soul's palace is become a prison:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Ah, would she break from hence, that this my body

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Might in the ground be closed up in rest!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For never henceforth shall I joy again,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Never, O never shall I see more joy!

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I cannot weep; for all my body's moisture

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Scarce serves to quench my furnace-burning heart:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nor can my tongue unload my heart's great burthen;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For selfsame wind that I should speak withal

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Is kindling coals that fires all my breast,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And burns me up with flames that tears would quench.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: To weep is to make less the depth of grief:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Tears then for babes; blows and revenge for me

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Richard, I bear thy name; I'll venge thy death,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Or die renowned by attempting it.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: His name that valiant duke hath left with thee;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: His dukedom and his chair with me is left.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nay, if thou be that princely eagle's bird,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Show thy descent by gazing 'gainst the sun:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For chair and dukedom, throne and kingdom say;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Either that is thine, or else thou wert not his.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: March. Enter WARWICK, MONTAGUE, and their army

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now, fair lords! What fare? what news abroad?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Great Lord of Warwick, if we should recount

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Our baleful news, and at each word's deliverance

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Stab poniards in our flesh till all were told,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The words would add more anguish than the wounds.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: O valiant lord, the Duke of York is slain!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O Warwick, Warwick! that Plantagenet,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Which held three dearly as his soul's redemption,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Is by the stern Lord Clifford done to death.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ten days ago I drown'd these news in tears;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now, to add more measure to your woes,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I come to tell you things sith then befall'n.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: After the bloody fray at Wakefield fought,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were brought me of your loss and his depart.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I, then in London keeper of the king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Muster'd my soldiers, gather'd flocks of friends,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And very well appointed, as I thought,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: March'd toward Saint Alban's to intercept the queen,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Bearing the king in my behalf along;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For by my scouts I was advertised

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That she was coming with a full intent

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To dash our late decree in parliament

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Touching King Henry's oath and your succession.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Short tale to make, we at Saint Alban's met

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Our battles join'd, and both sides fiercely fought:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But whether 'twas the coldness of the king,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Who look'd full gently on his warlike queen,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: That robb'd my soldiers of their heated spleen;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or whether 'twas report of her success;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or more than common fear of Clifford's rigour,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Who thunders to his captives blood and death,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I cannot judge: but to conclude with truth,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Their weapons like to lightning came and went;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Our soldiers', like the night-owl's lazy flight,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or like an idle thresher with a flail,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I cheer'd them up with justice of our cause,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With promise of high pay and great rewards:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But all in vain; they had no heart to fight,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And we in them no hope to win the day;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So that we fled; the king unto the queen;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Lord George your brother, Norfolk and myself,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In haste, post-haste, are come to join with you:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For in the marches here we heard you were,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Making another head to fight again.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Where is the Duke of Norfolk, gentle Warwick?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And when came George from Burgundy to England?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Some six miles off the duke is with the soldiers;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And for your brother, he was lately sent

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With aid of soldiers to this needful war.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: 'Twas odds, belike, when valiant Warwick fled:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Oft have I heard his praises in pursuit,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But ne'er till now his scandal of retire.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Nor now my scandal, Richard, dost thou hear;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Can pluck the diadem from faint Henry's head,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And wring the awful sceptre from his fist,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were he as famous and as bold in war

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: As he is famed for mildness, peace, and prayer.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I know it well, Lord Warwick; blame me not:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: 'Tis love I bear thy glories makes me speak.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But in this troublous time what's to be done?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Shall we go throw away our coats of steel,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And wrap our bodies in black mourning gowns,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Numbering our Ave-Maries with our beads?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Or shall we on the helmets of our foes

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Tell our devotion with revengeful arms?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If for the last, say ay, and to it, lords.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, therefore Warwick came to seek you out;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And therefore comes my brother Montague.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Attend me, lords. The proud insulting queen,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With Clifford and the haught Northumberland,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And of their feather many more proud birds,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Have wrought the easy-melting king like wax.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: He swore consent to your succession,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: His oath enrolled in the parliament;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now to London all the crew are gone,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To frustrate both his oath and what beside

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: May make against the house of Lancaster.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Their power, I think, is thirty thousand strong:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Now, if the help of Norfolk and myself,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: With all the friends that thou, brave Earl of March,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Amongst the loving Welshmen canst procure,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Will but amount to five and twenty thousand,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why, Via! to London will we march amain,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And once again bestride our foaming steeds,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And once again cry 'Charge upon our foes!'

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But never once again turn back and fly.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ay, now methinks I hear great Warwick speak:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ne'er may he live to see a sunshine day,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That cries 'Retire,' if Warwick bid him stay.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Lord Warwick, on thy shoulder will I lean;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And when thou fail'st--as God forbid the hour!--

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Must Edward fall, which peril heaven forfend!

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: No longer Earl of March, but Duke of York:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The next degree is England's royal throne;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: In every borough as we pass along;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And he that throws not up his cap for joy

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Shall for the fault make forfeit of his head.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: King Edward, valiant Richard, Montague,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Stay we no longer, dreaming of renown,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: But sound the trumpets, and about our task.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Then, Clifford, were thy heart as hard as steel,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As thou hast shown it flinty by thy deeds,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I come to pierce it, or to give thee mine.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Then strike up drums: God and Saint George for us!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now! what news?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The Duke of Norfolk sends you word by me,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The queen is coming with a puissant host;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And craves your company for speedy counsel.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why then it sorts, brave warriors, let's away.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE II. Before York.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET,  PRINCE EDWARD, CLIFFORD, and NORTHUMBERLAND, with drum and trumpets

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Welcome, my lord, to this brave town of York.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yonder's the head of that arch-enemy

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That sought to be encompass'd with your crown:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ay, as the rocks cheer them that fear their wreck:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To see this sight, it irks my very soul.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Withhold revenge, dear God! 'tis not my fault,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nor wittingly have I infringed my vow.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My gracious liege, this too much lenity

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And harmful pity must be laid aside.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To whom do lions cast their gentle looks?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Not to the beast that would usurp their den.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Whose hand is that the forest bear doth lick?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Not his that spoils her young before her face.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who 'scapes the lurking serpent's mortal sting?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Not he that sets his foot upon her back.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The smallest worm will turn being trodden on,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And doves will peck in safeguard of their brood.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ambitious York doth level at thy crown,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He, but a duke, would have his son a king,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And raise his issue, like a loving sire;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Thou, being a king, blest with a goodly son,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Didst yield consent to disinherit him,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Which argued thee a most unloving father.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Unreasonable creatures feed their young;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And though man's face be fearful to their eyes,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Yet, in protection of their tender ones,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who hath not seen them, even with those wings

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Which sometime they have used with fearful flight,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Make war with him that climb'd unto their nest,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Offer their own lives in their young's defence?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: For shame, my liege, make them your precedent!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Were it not pity that this goodly boy

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Should lose his birthright by his father's fault,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And long hereafter say unto his child,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: 'What my great-grandfather and his grandsire got

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My careless father fondly gave away'?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ah, what a shame were this! Look on the boy;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And let his manly face, which promiseth

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Successful fortune, steel thy melting heart

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Full well hath Clifford play'd the orator,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Inferring arguments of mighty force.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: But, Clifford, tell me, didst thou never hear

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: That things ill-got had ever bad success?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And happy always was it for that son

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whose father for his hoarding went to hell?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I'll leave my son my virtuous deeds behind;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And would my father had left me no more!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For all the rest is held at such a rate

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: As brings a thousand-fold more care to keep

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than in possession and jot of pleasure.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, cousin York! would thy best friends did know

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How it doth grieve me that thy head is here!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: My lord, cheer up your spirits: our foes are nigh,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And this soft courage makes your followers faint.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: You promised knighthood to our forward son:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Unsheathe your sword, and dub him presently.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Edward, kneel down.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And learn this lesson, draw thy sword in right.

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: My gracious father, by your kingly leave,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: I'll draw it as apparent to the crown,

speaker: PRINCE
text_entry: And in that quarrel use it to the death.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Why, that is spoken like a toward prince.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Royal commanders, be in readiness:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: For with a band of thirty thousand men

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Comes Warwick, backing of the Duke of York;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And in the towns, as they do march along,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Proclaims him king, and many fly to him:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Darraign your battle, for they are at hand.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I would your highness would depart the field:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The queen hath best success when you are absent.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ay, good my lord, and leave us to our fortune.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Why, that's my fortune too; therefore I'll stay.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Be it with resolution then to fight.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: My royal father, cheer these noble lords

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And hearten those that fight in your defence:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Unsheathe your sword, good father; cry 'Saint George!'

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: March. Enter EDWARD, GEORGE, RICHARD, WARWICK, NORFOLK, MONTAGUE, and Soldiers

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now, perjured Henry! wilt thou kneel for grace,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And set thy diadem upon my head;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Or bide the mortal fortune of the field?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Go, rate thy minions, proud insulting boy!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Becomes it thee to be thus bold in terms

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Before thy sovereign and thy lawful king?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I am his king, and he should bow his knee;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I was adopted heir by his consent:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Since when, his oath is broke; for, as I hear,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: You, that are king, though he do wear the crown,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Have caused him, by new act of parliament,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: To blot out me, and put his own son in.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And reason too:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Who should succeed the father but the son?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Are you there, butcher? O, I cannot speak!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ay, crook-back, here I stand to answer thee,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Or any he the proudest of thy sort.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: 'Twas you that kill'd young Rutland, was it not?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Ay, and old York, and yet not satisfied.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For God's sake, lords, give signal to the fight.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: What say'st thou, Henry, wilt thou yield the crown?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why, how now, long-tongued Warwick! dare you speak?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: When you and I met at Saint Alban's last,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Your legs did better service than your hands.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then 'twas my turn to fly, and now 'tis thine.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: You said so much before, and yet you fled.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: 'Twas not your valour, Clifford, drove me thence.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: No, nor your manhood that durst make you stay.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Northumberland, I hold thee reverently.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Break off the parley; for scarce I can refrain

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The execution of my big-swoln heart

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Upon that Clifford, that cruel child-killer.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I slew thy father, call'st thou him a child?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ay, like a dastard and a treacherous coward,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As thou didst kill our tender brother Rutland;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But ere sunset I'll make thee curse the deed.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have done with words, my lords, and hear me speak.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I prithee, give no limits to my tongue:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: I am a king, and privileged to speak.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My liege, the wound that bred this meeting here

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Cannot be cured by words; therefore be still.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Then, executioner, unsheathe thy sword:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: By him that made us all, I am resolved

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: that Clifford's manhood lies upon his tongue.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Say, Henry, shall I have my right, or no?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: A thousand men have broke their fasts to-day,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That ne'er shall dine unless thou yield the crown.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: If thou deny, their blood upon thy head;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For York in justice puts his armour on.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: If that be right which Warwick says is right,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: There is no wrong, but every thing is right.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Whoever got thee, there thy mother stands;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For, well I wot, thou hast thy mother's tongue.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But thou art neither like thy sire nor dam;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But like a foul mis-shapen stigmatic,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Mark'd by the destinies to be avoided,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As venom toads, or lizards' dreadful stings.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Iron of Naples hid with English gilt,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Whose father bears the title of a king,--

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: As if a channel should be call'd the sea,--

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Shamest thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: To let thy tongue detect thy base-born heart?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: A wisp of straw were worth a thousand crowns,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: To make this shameless callet know herself.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Helen of Greece was fairer far than thou,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Although thy husband may be Menelaus;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And ne'er was Agamemnon's brother wrong'd

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: By that false woman, as this king by thee.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: His father revell'd in the heart of France,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And tamed the king, and made the dauphin stoop;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And had he match'd according to his state,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: He might have kept that glory to this day;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: But when he took a beggar to his bed,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And graced thy poor sire with his bridal-day,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Even then that sunshine brew'd a shower for him,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That wash'd his father's fortunes forth of France,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And heap'd sedition on his crown at home.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Hadst thou been meek, our title still had slept;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And we, in pity of the gentle king,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Had slipp'd our claim until another age.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: But when we saw our sunshine made thy spring,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And that thy summer bred us no increase,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: We set the axe to thy usurping root;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And though the edge hath something hit ourselves,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Yet, know thou, since we have begun to strike,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: We'll never leave till we have hewn thee down,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Or bathed thy growing with our heated bloods.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And, in this resolution, I defy thee;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Not willing any longer conference,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Since thou deniest the gentle king to speak.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Sound trumpets! let our bloody colours wave!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And either victory, or else a grave.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Stay, Edward.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: No, wrangling woman, we'll no longer stay:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: These words will cost ten thousand lives this day.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: SCENE III. A field of battle between Towton and Saxton, in

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Yorkshire.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Alarum. Excursions. Enter WARWICK

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Forspent with toil, as runners with a race,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I lay me down a little while to breathe;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For strokes received, and many blows repaid,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Have robb'd my strong-knit sinews of their strength,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And spite of spite needs must I rest awhile.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter EDWARD, running

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Smile, gentle heaven! or strike, ungentle death!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: How now, my lord! what hap? what hope of good?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter GEORGE

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Our hap is loss, our hope but sad despair;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Our ranks are broke, and ruin follows us:

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: What counsel give you? whither shall we fly?

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Bootless is flight, they follow us with wings;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And weak we are and cannot shun pursuit.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Enter RICHARD

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Ah, Warwick, why hast thou withdrawn thyself?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Broach'd with the steely point of Clifford's lance;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And in the very pangs of death he cried,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Like to a dismal clangour heard from far,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: 'Warwick, revenge! brother, revenge my death!'

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: So, underneath the belly of their steeds,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That stain'd their fetlocks in his smoking blood,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: The noble gentleman gave up the ghost.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I'll kill my horse, because I will not fly.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Why stand we like soft-hearted women here,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And look upon, as if the tragedy

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Were play'd in jest by counterfeiting actors?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Here on my knee I vow to God above,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I'll never pause again, never stand still,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Or fortune given me measure of revenge.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: O Warwick, I do bend my knee with thine;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And in this vow do chain my soul to thine!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And, ere my knee rise from the earth's cold face,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to thee,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Thou setter up and plucker down of kings,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Beseeching thee, if with they will it stands

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That to my foes this body must be prey,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Yet that thy brazen gates of heaven may ope,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And give sweet passage to my sinful soul!

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now, lords, take leave until we meet again,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Where'er it be, in heaven or in earth.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Brother, give me thy hand; and, gentle Warwick,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Let me embrace thee in my weary arms:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I, that did never weep, now melt with woe

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That winter should cut off our spring-time so.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Away, away! Once more, sweet lords farewell.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Yet let us all together to our troops,

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And give them leave to fly that will not stay;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And call them pillars that will stand to us;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: And, if we thrive, promise them such rewards

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: As victors wear at the Olympian games:

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: This may plant courage in their quailing breasts;

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: For yet is hope of life and victory.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Forslow no longer, make we hence amain.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: SCENE IV. Another part of the field.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Excursions. Enter RICHARD and CLIFFORD

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Now, Clifford, I have singled thee alone:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Suppose this arm is for the Duke of York,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: And this for Rutland; both bound to revenge,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Wert thou environ'd with a brazen wall.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Now, Richard, I am with thee here alone:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: This is the hand that stabb'd thy father York;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And this the hand that slew thy brother Rutland;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And here's the heart that triumphs in their death

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And cheers these hands that slew thy sire and brother

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: To execute the like upon thyself;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And so, have at thee!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: They fight. WARWICK comes; CLIFFORD flies

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Nay Warwick, single out some other chase;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For I myself will hunt this wolf to death.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the field.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Alarum. Enter KING HENRY VI alone

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: This battle fares like to the morning's war,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When dying clouds contend with growing light,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Can neither call it perfect day nor night.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Now sways it this way, like a mighty sea

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Forced by the tide to combat with the wind;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Forced to retire by fury of the wind:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Now one the better, then another best;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Yet neither conqueror nor conquered:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So is the equal of this fell war.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Here on this molehill will I sit me down.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To whom God will, there be the victory!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Have chid me from the battle; swearing both

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: They prosper best of all when I am thence.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Would I were dead! if God's good will were so;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For what is in this world but grief and woe?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O God! methinks it were a happy life,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To be no better than a homely swain;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To sit upon a hill, as I do now,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To carve out dials quaintly, point by point,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thereby to see the minutes how they run,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many make the hour full complete;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many hours bring about the day;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many days will finish up the year;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How many years a mortal man may live.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When this is known, then to divide the times:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I tend my flock;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I take my rest;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I contemplate;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many hours must I sport myself;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many days my ewes have been with young;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many weeks ere the poor fools will ean:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So many years ere I shall shear the fleece:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: So minutes, hours, days, months, and years,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Pass'd over to the end they were created,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Ah, what a life were this! how sweet! how lovely!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To shepherds looking on their silly sheep,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Than doth a rich embroider'd canopy

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To kings that fear their subjects' treachery?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O, yes, it doth; a thousand-fold it doth.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And to conclude, the shepherd's homely curds,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: All which secure and sweetly he enjoys,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is far beyond a prince's delicates,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His viands sparkling in a golden cup,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: His body couched in a curious bed,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Alarum. Enter a Son that has killed his father, dragging in the dead body

speaker: Son
text_entry: Ill blows the wind that profits nobody.

speaker: Son
text_entry: This man, whom hand to hand I slew in fight,

speaker: Son
text_entry: May be possessed with some store of crowns;

speaker: Son
text_entry: And I, that haply take them from him now,

speaker: Son
text_entry: May yet ere night yield both my life and them

speaker: Son
text_entry: To some man else, as this dead man doth me.

speaker: Son
text_entry: Who's this? O God! it is my father's face,

speaker: Son
text_entry: Whom in this conflict I unwares have kill'd.

speaker: Son
text_entry: O heavy times, begetting such events!

speaker: Son
text_entry: From London by the king was I press'd forth;

speaker: Son
text_entry: My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man,

speaker: Son
text_entry: Came on the part of York, press'd by his master;

speaker: Son
text_entry: And I, who at his hands received my life, him

speaker: Son
text_entry: Have by my hands of life bereaved him.

speaker: Son
text_entry: Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did!

speaker: Son
text_entry: And pardon, father, for I knew not thee!

speaker: Son
text_entry: My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks;

speaker: Son
text_entry: And no more words till they have flow'd their fill.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O piteous spectacle! O bloody times!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whiles lions war and battle for their dens,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Weep, wretched man, I'll aid thee tear for tear;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And let our hearts and eyes, like civil war,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Be blind with tears, and break o'ercharged with grief.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Enter a Father that has killed his son, bringing in the body

speaker: Father
text_entry: Thou that so stoutly hast resisted me,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold:

speaker: Father
text_entry: For I have bought it with an hundred blows.

speaker: Father
text_entry: But let me see: is this our foeman's face?

speaker: Father
text_entry: Ah, no, no, no, it is mine only son!

speaker: Father
text_entry: Ah, boy, if any life be left in thee,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Throw up thine eye! see, see what showers arise,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Blown with the windy tempest of my heart,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Upon thy words, that kill mine eye and heart!

speaker: Father
text_entry: O, pity, God, this miserable age!

speaker: Father
text_entry: What stratagems, how fell, how butcherly,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Erroneous, mutinous and unnatural,

speaker: Father
text_entry: This deadly quarrel daily doth beget!

speaker: Father
text_entry: O boy, thy father gave thee life too soon,

speaker: Father
text_entry: And hath bereft thee of thy life too late!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Woe above woe! grief more than common grief!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O that my death would stay these ruthful deeds!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: O pity, pity, gentle heaven, pity!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The red rose and the white are on his face,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The fatal colours of our striving houses:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The one his purple blood right well resembles;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: The other his pale cheeks, methinks, presenteth:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Wither one rose, and let the other flourish;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: If you contend, a thousand lives must wither.

speaker: Son
text_entry: How will my mother for a father's death

speaker: Son
text_entry: Take on with me and ne'er be satisfied!

speaker: Father
text_entry: How will my wife for slaughter of my son

speaker: Father
text_entry: Shed seas of tears and ne'er be satisfied!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: How will the country for these woful chances

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Misthink the king and not be satisfied!

speaker: Son
text_entry: Was ever son so rued a father's death?

speaker: Father
text_entry: Was ever father so bemoan'd his son?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Was ever king so grieved for subjects' woe?

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Much is your sorrow; mine ten times so much.

speaker: Son
text_entry: I'll bear thee hence, where I may weep my fill.

speaker: Son
text_entry: Exit with the body

speaker: Father
text_entry: These arms of mine shall be thy winding-sheet;

speaker: Father
text_entry: My heart, sweet boy, shall be thy sepulchre,

speaker: Father
text_entry: For from my heart thine image ne'er shall go;

speaker: Father
text_entry: My sighing breast shall be thy funeral bell;

speaker: Father
text_entry: And so obsequious will thy father be,

speaker: Father
text_entry: Even for the loss of thee, having no more,

speaker: Father
text_entry: As Priam was for all his valiant sons.

speaker: Father
text_entry: I'll bear thee hence; and let them fight that will,

speaker: Father
text_entry: For I have murdered where I should not kill.

speaker: Father
text_entry: Exit with the body

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Sad-hearted men, much overgone with care,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Here sits a king more woful than you are.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Alarums: excursions. Enter QUEEN MARGARET, PRINCE EDWARD, and EXETER

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Fly, father, fly! for all your friends are fled,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: And Warwick rages like a chafed bull:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Away! for death doth hold us in pursuit.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Mount you, my lord; towards Berwick post amain:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Having the fearful flying hare in sight,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And bloody steel grasp'd in their ireful hands,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Are at our backs; and therefore hence amain.

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Away! for vengeance comes along with them:

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Nay, stay not to expostulate, make speed;

speaker: EXETER
text_entry: Or else come after: I'll away before.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Not that I fear to stay, but love to go

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Whither the queen intends. Forward; away!

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: SCENE VI. Another part of the field.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: A loud alarum. Enter CLIFFORD, wounded

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Here burns my candle out; ay, here it dies,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Which, whiles it lasted, gave King Henry light.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: O Lancaster, I fear thy overthrow

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: More than my body's parting with my soul!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: My love and fear glued many friends to thee;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And, now I fall, thy tough commixture melts.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Impairing Henry, strengthening misproud York,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The common people swarm like summer flies;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And whither fly the gnats but to the sun?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And who shines now but Henry's enemies?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: O Phoebus, hadst thou never given consent

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: That Phaethon should cheque thy fiery steeds,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Thy burning car never had scorch'd the earth!

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And, Henry, hadst thou sway'd as kings should do,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Or as thy father and his father did,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Giving no ground unto the house of York,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: They never then had sprung like summer flies;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I and ten thousand in this luckless realm

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Had left no mourning widows for our death;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And thou this day hadst kept thy chair in peace.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And what makes robbers bold but too much lenity?

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Bootless are plaints, and cureless are my wounds;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: No way to fly, nor strength to hold out flight:

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The foe is merciless, and will not pity;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: For at their hands I have deserved no pity.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: The air hath got into my deadly wounds,

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: And much effuse of blood doth make me faint.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Come, York and Richard, Warwick and the rest;

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: I stabb'd your fathers' bosoms, split my breast.

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: He faints

speaker: CLIFFORD
text_entry: Alarum and retreat. Enter EDWARD, GEORGE, RICHARD, MONTAGUE, WARWICK, and Soldiers

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now breathe we, lords: good fortune bids us pause,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And smooth the frowns of war with peaceful looks.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Some troops pursue the bloody-minded queen,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That led calm Henry, though he were a king,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: As doth a sail, fill'd with a fretting gust,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Command an argosy to stem the waves.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: But think you, lords, that Clifford fled with them?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: No, 'tis impossible he should escape,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For, though before his face I speak the words

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Your brother Richard mark'd him for the grave:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And wheresoe'er he is, he's surely dead.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: CLIFFORD groans, and dies

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Whose soul is that which takes her heavy leave?

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: A deadly groan, like life and death's departing.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: See who it is: and, now the battle's ended,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: If friend or foe, let him be gently used.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Revoke that doom of mercy, for 'tis Clifford;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Who not contented that he lopp'd the branch

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: In hewing Rutland when his leaves put forth,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: But set his murdering knife unto the root

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I mean our princely father, Duke of York.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: From off the gates of York fetch down the head,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Your father's head, which Clifford placed there;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Instead whereof let this supply the room:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Measure for measure must be answered.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Bring forth that fatal screech-owl to our house,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: That nothing sung but death to us and ours:

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Now death shall stop his dismal threatening sound,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And his ill-boding tongue no more shall speak.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: I think his understanding is bereft.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Speak, Clifford, dost thou know who speaks to thee?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And he nor sees nor hears us what we say.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: O, would he did! and so perhaps he doth:

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: 'Tis but his policy to counterfeit,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Because he would avoid such bitter taunts

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Which in the time of death he gave our father.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: If so thou think'st, vex him with eager words.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Clifford, ask mercy and obtain no grace.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Clifford, repent in bootless penitence.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Clifford, devise excuses for thy faults.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: While we devise fell tortures for thy faults.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Thou pitied'st Rutland; I will pity thee.

speaker: GEORGE
text_entry: Where's Captain Margaret, to fence you now?

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: They mock thee, Clifford: swear as thou wast wont.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: What, not an oath? nay, then the world goes hard

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: I know by that he's dead; and, by my soul,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: If this right hand would buy two hour's life,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: That I in all despite might rail at him,

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: This hand should chop it off, and with the

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: issuing blood

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Stifle the villain whose unstanched thirst

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: York and young Rutland could not satisfy.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Ay, but he's dead: off with the traitor's head,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And rear it in the place your father's stands.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And now to London with triumphant march,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: There to be crowned England's royal king:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And ask the Lady Bona for thy queen:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: So shalt thou sinew both these lands together;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And, having France thy friend, thou shalt not dread

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: The scatter'd foe that hopes to rise again;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Yet look to have them buzz to offend thine ears.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: First will I see the coronation;

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: And then to Brittany I'll cross the sea,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be;

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: For in thy shoulder do I build my seat,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And never will I undertake the thing

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Richard, I will create thee Duke of Gloucester,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: And George, of Clarence: Warwick, as ourself,

speaker: EDWARD
text_entry: Shall do and undo as him pleaseth best.

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloucester;

speaker: RICHARD
text_entry: For Gloucester's dukedom is too ominous.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Tut, that's a foolish observation:

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Richard, be Duke of Gloucester. Now to London,

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: To see these honours in possession.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE I. A forest in the north of England.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter two Keepers, with cross-bows in their hands

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Under this thick-grown brake we'll shroud ourselves;

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: For through this laund anon the deer will come;

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: And in this covert will we make our stand,

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Culling the principal of all the deer.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: I'll stay above the hill, so both may shoot.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: That cannot be; the noise of thy cross-bow

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Will scare the herd, and so my shoot is lost.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Here stand we both, and aim we at the best:

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: And, for the time shall not seem tedious,

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: I'll tell thee what befell me on a day

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: In this self-place where now we mean to stand.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Here comes a man; let's stay till he be past.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Enter KING HENRY VI, disguised, with a prayerbook

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: From Scotland am I stol'n, even of pure love,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To greet mine own land with my wishful sight.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No, Harry, Harry, 'tis no land of thine;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy place is fill'd, thy sceptre wrung from thee,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Thy balm wash'd off wherewith thou wast anointed:

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No bending knee will call thee Caesar now,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No humble suitors press to speak for right,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: No, not a man comes for redress of thee;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For how can I help them, and not myself?

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Ay, here's a deer whose skin's a keeper's fee:

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: This is the quondam king; let's seize upon him.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Let me embrace thee, sour adversity,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For wise men say it is the wisest course.

speaker: Second Keeper
text_entry: Why linger we? let us lay hands upon him.

speaker: First Keeper
text_entry: Forbear awhile; we'll hear a little more.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: My queen and son are gone to France for aid;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And, as I hear, the great commanding Warwick

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Is thither gone, to crave the French king's sister

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: To wife for Edward: if this news be true,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: Poor queen and son, your labour is but lost;

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: For Warwick is a subtle orator,

speaker: KING HENRY VI
text_entry: And Lewis a prince soon won with moving words.

speaker: KING HENRY VI
